A 'presidential election' was held in France on 22 April 2012 (or 21 April in
some overseas departments and territories), with a second round run-off held on
6 May (or 5 May for those same territories) to elect the President of France
(who is also ex officio one of the two joint heads of state of Andorra, a
sovereign state). The incumbent Nicolas Sarkozy was running for a second
successive and, under the terms of the constitution, final term in the election.

The first round ended with the selection of FranÃ§ois Hollande and Nicolas
Sarkozy as second round participants, as neither of them received a majority of
votes cast in the first round. Hollande won the runoff with 51.64% of the vote
to Sarkozy's 48.36%. MinistÃ¨re de l'Interieur:
[http://elections.interieur.gouv.fr/PR2012/FE.html Ãlection PrÃ©sidentielle 2012,
RÃ©sultats 2nd tour]

The presidential election was followed by a legislative election in June and
was the second to feature candidates not to have been in politics under Charles
de Gaulle.
